reviewText:
‚Äú8-Ball - Corner Pocket‚Äù
‚ÄòPool Nation‚Äô is a fun, polished Billiards simulator and a bargain at its $1 pricetag (Steam Fall Sale 2014). Released as the maiden offering from Cherry Pop Games, it‚Äôs gorgeous visuals, multiple game modes, lengthy campaign and lots of unlockables will keep Pool fans coming back for more.

Campaign | Gameplay: Gamers have the choice of playing standard 8-ball or variations like 9-ball, Rotation, Endurance, Sudden Death etc across a variety of visually stunning locations / pool halls. A lengthy campaign mode (against AI opponents) allows you to perfect your game and strive toward numerous unlockables including new locations, pool table decals, new ball styles and cue styles. Additionally, the online mode allows you to match up with friends or other online players in single matches, Tournaments or King of the Hill events. Multiple difficulty levels (from Novice to Pro), a spot on physics engine, responsive controls, and a great soundtrack make this the best Pool game to date.

Flaws: In considering its biggest issues ‚Äì 1. Game Stability is poor (Tabbing to windows results in an insta-crash) and 2. Online Gaming is largely dead (Bring your own friends). Additionally, the developers have pushed the previously promised ‚ÄòTrick Shot‚Äô mode to the next release, and the lack of Co-op play is disappointing as well.

Overall, ‚ÄòPool Nation‚Äô is the best conception of a Billiards game to date and fans of the real game will find this a fun, polished distraction. But, even ardent fans soon realize that Pool without the smoky basement rooms, uneven cues, pitchers of beer, chatty girls, side-bets and bar-room trash talk, is a somewhat hollow experience. Recommended on Sale (Best played with Friends) - Rated (7/10)

reviewText:
Right off the bat, one thing that will catch your attention is the variety of game types.  Most billiards games like to focus only on either 8- or 9-ball.  Those games are here, but they do not stop at that.  Along the game, other games like Rotation and Golf are in the mix.  With nine different ways currently available with Snooker and Trick coming soon, there are plenty of ways to play.

Another strong point about the game is the controls.  Like in any other pool game, being able to control the cue ball is important.  Most games simply allow you to aim the ball and adjust the power.  Even though most games stop at this, there are more options to offer.  By being able to adjust the angle of the cue stick as well as where on the cue ball to aim, it gives the option of doing jump and swerve shots, something most billiard games leave out.  Additionally, with a full tutorial teaching how to do all of these moves, it does not take long before they become second nature.

Beyond all the gameplay details, a nice touch about the game is the amount of customization available.  Even games that try to simulate pro billiards tend to stick to a single, sometimes sponsored look throughout the game.  This one goes beyond the basics.  As soon as you start a game, the highly detailed and moving locals make it feel like you are in what could be a real location.  As you keep progressing, at least a dozen locals, cue sticks, ball sets, and even table decals make it that regardless your taste, there is plenty to see even from a visual standpoint.

Once the single-player game is over, there is still more to play.  Through online multiplayer, it is possible to keep playing with others.  It is even possible to create tournaments to learn who the best player is.  However, the one drawback is that there is no local multiplayer mode available.  This means that in order to play with another person in the same room, the two of you must play through a network.  This feels like a major oversight.  A simple hot seat patch would have made that the game could be a great party game.  Even without local multiplayer, this is still a great package that any billiards fan can easily enjoy.

The difficulties I have with Pool Nation start in the fact that I already know ho to play pool. I will explain: The english in Pool Nation does not accurately represent the way in which a ball would travel with said spin. Top and bottom english when making a cut shot can cause the cue ball to travel more left or right on the deflection, and this is not represented at all.

Left/right english isn't actually as useful on a pool table as an amateur might think. I rarely use left/right english in real pool, as top/bottom english can account for most necessary ball control.

As I can best explain it: Top and bottom english account most for how the cue ball deflects off the object ball, and left/right english effects the way the cue ball deflects off rails. There is a small amount of effect with left/right on ball deflection, and top/bottom on rail deflection, but it is very slight.

This has to do with the fact that the rail is a solid unmovable force, and ball deflection is sympathetic to mass/friction.

My previous pool experience makes this game very unintuitive!

Pool Nation is one of the most polished indie games of 2013- the animations are shiny and smooth, the gameplay is responsive and the physics are realistic. You won't find yourself screaming at this game for bouncing your balls in the wrong direction, or glitching out and dropping your cue ball through the table. With eleven game modes including tournaments, online play, and single-player endurance mode; as well as a slew of collectables to unlock, Pool Nation has no shortage of goodies to keep gameplay fresh.

The single player component revolves primarily around tournaments where you take on AI challengers of ever increasing difficulty. Each match has an associated list of challenges, and completing them unlocks a variety of cosmetic changes like cues and balls. Standard games like 9 ball are present along with more interesting options like Golf, which challenges you to put specific balls into specific pockets. There‚Äôs also a time attack style mode, where balls spawn on the table and you have to sink as many as possible in the time limit. There are Free Play, Versus, and Online modes present too, but I had a hard time finding anyone to challenge online.

Pool Nation is a great looking game that features bright and shiny graphics that makes each game, literally, feel new and different. There are some good themes on the game's soundtrack, and though the game's controls look difficult to use, they aren't difficult to learn. There are also options that can be easily turned on or off to give players assists in a game including arrows that point at the next balls that need to be hit or arrows that show where a ball will travel when hit. All of these features combine to make an excellent presentation for Pool Nation.

But is it fun? In short stints I definitely enjoyed playing the game, but it isn‚Äôt the type of thing I‚Äôd want to play for hours at a time. Having said that, I think Pool Nation is the kind of experience that would be a hit at a house party. If you‚Äôve been searching far and wide for a Billiards simulator, and don‚Äôt have room for an actual table, Pool Nation is probably the solution. The physics are solid, the controls allow for extreme fine tuning of shots, and everything looks super shiny. A few more game types would be welcome, but for $10 Pool Nation is the gold standard in the category.

reviewText:
Excellent game for a variety of reasons. I like the attention that was put into the details. Everything looks really nice, there are quirky opponents, and most importantly the gameplay is excellent.
There are two campaigns: one for 8-ball and one for 9-ball. Both have challenges each match to help keep the game fresh. Some example challenges are complete a trick shot or have a streak of potted balls. Their are also a variety of opponents with little biographies that you can choose to read or not. It is nice how this game is not too story dependent as I feel that would interrupt the flow. Each campaign takes a while to get through and was fun for me until completion.
Another mode I've spent time on is endurance mode. It is an addicting, time sensitive, mode in which you try to continuosly pot balls while new balls are being added at increasingly fast intervals. I've spent at least an hour just with that mode, chasing a new time record.

reviewText:
First off, this is the best looking pool game I have ever played.  Period.
Beautiful pool tables, balls, and environments that are fully fleshed out and animated to give you a real sense of immersion.

The game is full of details that kept surprising me.  Some of them are so subtle that you can't even notice it unless you are watching the replay.  Here are a few things you will find:

* 3rd dimension: this isn't a simple pool game where balls stick to the table.  All pool balls can be knocked off, up in the air, and over other balls (given enough force).
* When hit certain ways, chalk will fall off stick and sprinkle on the table.
* Tiny woven texture on table material when you zoom in close
* Sides of table (bumpers) actually give and bend in when a ball hits them with force (very hard to notice without replay!)

For single player there is enough to keep you busy for awhile with tournaments in various game types against different AI.  One thing I found keeping my interest is bonuses you can try for on each game in a tournament.  For instance one might have a bonus for pulling off a jump shot during the match.  You can still win the game, but there will be a bonus for doing the jump shot.  Earning these stars while winning makes for a fun challenge.
There are also many ball styles, cue sticks, and locations to unlock through single player.  So far every ball set I have unlocked has been great looking and is a good incentive to keep playing and unlock more.

For multiplayer, it is fully functional in both same computer and online play.  Unsurprisingly you have to wait awhile for a game to show up, but that's less the fault of the game and more of the popularity of online pool :).

Last I should go over the physics.  This is a tough point to argue because so many factors go into pool physics and without a doubt there is no game out there that is 100% accurate.  If you have ever seen a ball hit another ball at high speed in close up slow motion you'll see what I mean.  Not to mention there are many different ball sizes/weight, table materials and cue sticks used in different areas that add to the difficulty in comparing this to the real world.

All I can say for sure is the physics seem real and have been really fun.  Added to the ability to hit the ball just where I want at power levels I never could in RL the game makes you feel like a pool master.

Game is on sale for $1.99 currently.  Sell a couple summer trading cards and pick it up!

reviewText:
This game really caught my eye on steam, and how could it not, it‚Äôs so very very shiny. Released originally on PSN Cherry Pop ported their billiards game over to the PC and is available for $10 via steam.

What we have here is really a modern pool game. A sparkling beautiful graphics engine combined with an impressive realistic physics engine all to send shiny balls flying around a table. It‚Äôs smooth, it‚Äôs pretty, it‚Äôs gorgeous. (click on some of my high-res screenshots and see for yourself!) Really what else do you need to know? If you like pool games then it‚Äôs for you, if you don‚Äôt, all the shiny graphics in the world probably won‚Äôt change your mind. What you might expect from a pool game is all here, an 8-ball and 9-ball tour to play through with slowly increasing difficulty as well as some other game modes to throw in some variety.

There are also arbitrary points systems that award you points based upon added difficulty of shots (kinda like the way skater games give you points for harder tricks) and as you progress through each tour there are challenges to meet in each match to unlock extra goodies. It‚Äôs all your typical completionist fluff we‚Äôve grown to expect from games these days but they do add some extra challenge and drives you to try to be more creative as you play. I also found I enjoyed most of the challenge modes that are unlocked during the tour play although a couple get a little tedious and boring.

Everything in the game is well crafted, the table is high textured, the balls well polished and reflective, and even the backgrounds are rich with detail and eye candy. The art style is beautiful and there‚Äôs even interesting little blurbs written about each opponent you play against. But all of this eye candy is just background noise to distract you from pocketing those balls! The game really shines though when it comes to trick-shots. Jump shots, draw backs, kick shots, even riding the rail is all possible with the engine. With full control to put on as much english and angle on your shot as you‚Äôd like you can put together some pretty sweet shots. Thanks to the shot guides they are not very difficult to learn and once you start pulling them off with regularity your options with each shot open wide. Best of all, the AI knows and uses them just as well which creates quite a challenge as you progress through the game.

The trick-shots are definitely best seen in video as screenshots cannot do them proper justice. You‚Äôll be hopping over balls and making crazy draw backs in no time making you feel quite the awesome player. The game is, however, not without it‚Äôs flaws. A common complaint I have of many games, the music started to get annoying to me but this is not the first game I‚Äôve had to mute the music and play my own. It is also clear that it is a port rather than designed specifically for the PC.

The menus sometimes feel a bit awkward navigating with a mouse and I feel some of the controls are awkward. For example rotating my cue around the cue ball to line up a shot only involves moving mouse left or right, yet my natural inclination is to try to circle the mouse around the cue ball. It made for some very frustrating moments until I realized this. Also I found the video replay system to be- clunky at best. Still even with these small complaints I‚Äôd definitely recommend the game if you ever find yourself wanting to shoot some pool.

My review will cover the following:
1. What is good about the game
2. What is not so good

THE GOOD
First off, the game is absolutely beautiful in every way; beautifully optimized, beautiful physics, beautiful graphics, etc.
I've always enjoyed playing pool ever since I was young, whether it be at the arcade, bowling alley, or pool hall, I always enjoyed it; and up until this game, I considered the ONLY GOOD pool video game in existence is Pool Paradise[en.wikipedia.org], which I had owned for the Nintendo Gamecube and still have for pc. Pool Nation is a more modern version of Pool Paradise, doesn't have as many features as Pool Paradise (like Darts, Crazy Tables, Skee Ball, that canon and coconuts game, among things)
I feel Pool Nation doesn't really live up to Pool Paradise, but is a good pool game, nonetheless; less than five minutes into my first playthrough of Pool Nation, I was immediately addicted to it.

But enough rambling, let's get down to what's good in Pool Nation.
Quality:
Without a doubt, for an indie game, the quality is amazing. The optimization, which is usually lacking in indie games, is perfect.
Physics:
The physics engine is awesome, right up there with Pool Paradise. When I'd look at other pool games, other than Pool Paradise, the physics would be a disaster, either too stiff or too loose; Pool Nation's physics are as true to the real game as you can get. With precise cue control, you can curve, give spin, jump, etc, to your heart's content!
Textures:
The textures are beautiful; from the detailed wood grain of the cues, to the fine threads of the pool table mat, everything's in stunning detail. With realtime ball reflections to stunning environments, Pool Nation is in a league all its own!
Music:
An awesome soundtrack is there to set the mood and keep you company while you play. From light piano music, to downright funky, it's got you set. With each location having its own custom music pieces, the variety is right up there.
Unlocks:
As you progress and beat certain challenges, you can unlock new cues, ball sets, and mat decals; a vast array to accompany anyone's tastes and wants!
Sound:
As a sound designer, this is my bread and butter. Pool Nation's sounds are top notch; everything from the cue hitting the cue ball, the balls hitting each other, hitting the cushions, going into the pockets, and to bouncing off the table and hitting the floor are superb. I was actually surprised when I heard the ball bouncing on the floor after it left the table, nice and lively with reverb!
Endurance:
Not my most favorite gamemode ever, but it certainly is one that'll keep you on the edge of your seat, your palms will sweat, your heart will race, and will truly test how good and quick you are.
Slow mo:
The slow mo feature is a nice touch. Your last ball is going for the pocket, you're not sure if it'll make it, the slow mo kicks in showing the pocket, as the ball eases in in stunning, glossy, detail, it slowly reaches the end of the mat, you're on the edge of your seat...BOOM it tips off the edge and goes in, you win! It's also great for those action shots with the ball cruising into the pocket.
Replay:
The replay is awesome. Just pulled off the most amazing shot ever and want to see it again in slow mo? No problem, the replay feature's got your back! Everything from chalk dust to cushion distension can be seen in replay, and features allow you to slow down and move the camera to get a nice look on all the action that took place! reviewText:
This is quickly becoming my favorite game on Steam. It went on sale for a great price so I picked it up. I'm not great at pool, but I have always enjoyed playing it and figured it was worth the try.

-I can say that the physics seem spot on. I played as well in the game as I do in reality, with the balls reacting in very familiar ways.

-The sound is crisp and enjoyable. The music is soothing, though at times the looping can get tiresome.

-Visuals shouldn't be the focal point of this type of game, but it does look great. Devs went above and beyond in that regard. The presentation seems very hip, and has unique charm.

-The UI can be a bit troublesome at times, like when you want to select one thing with your mouse, and you end up selecting the menu option next to it for example. That is the only issue here, though. You aren't going to get lost in crazy menus, or complex brackets or anything. Very easy to navigate.

-The challenge is adjustable so that beginners and pros alike can sharpen their skills or just enjoy the experience.

I'm currently halfway through the first tournament, so I can't say much as far as the amount of content or number of play modes. There are small challenges to complete during each match, making those who want completion take special consideration within each. I might update this later on, who knows.

If you can catch this game on sale, go for it. It is worth the $10 price tag in my opinion, but I do have a soft spot for pool in general, so take that for what you will.

reviewText:
I love this game for 2 player local co-op.  We use 2 Steam Controllers and play via my Steam Link.

This is a fun little pool game that is great for players of all skill levels.  The controls are very intuitive and have been easily picked up by my 75 year old father and others.   We all like the music and find it contributes nicely to the overall relaxing nature of 2 player pool.

One of the great features is the versatile aiming aid which shows players the exact path of the cue ball and object ball as they aim and adjust spin and power.  As players get better they can shorten the length of the aid to increase the player skill required to make the shots.  In 2 player local co-op each player may choose the length of the aiming aid independent of the other player.  This means experts can have a very short aiming aid while less-experienced players may have a longer one.  This is a nifty way to handicap games that doesn't make new players feel pandered-to in my experience.

A couple of negatives are that the physics are a bit questionable at times, and the aiming aid can permit some absolutely ludicrous shots that would be impossible outside of a physics simulation.  The single player career seems to be nothing more than a way to purposefully gate content... even though you bought the game if you want all the locations and wingdings unlocked you have to buy the unlock" DLC or slog through the laborious and completely unfun "career".

All in all
date: I recommend this game for local co-op play and pretty much no other reason.  Several times I've checked out the online lobbies and couldn't find anybody to ever play with though YMMV."

This is a very nicely presented pool game, with everything that a fan of the game would want. It has nine-ball pool (pot the balls in sequence and whoever pots the last ball is the winner), eight-ball pool (the stripes and solids version), trick shots and online play.

Every match in the campaign mode has extra challenges that make each game different and help to ramp up the difficulty. For example, a challenge might be to get a four-ball streak, perform a kick shot, etc. There‚Äôs also a few bonus rounds with different modes of play.

Tutorials are excellent. It guides you through each step of the shot and makes it very easy to perform impressive stuff like kick shots, jump shots, combo shots, swerve shots and more. There's a surprisingly large amount of ways to hit a ball.

You can unlock different designs for the tables, cues and balls. You also unlock different locations to play pool in. These are purely cosmetic, but they look great and add to the overall experience.

If the idea of playing pool appeals to you - definitely get this. I personally have very minimal interest in pool, but it‚Äôs all so well done that I'm enjoying it anyway.

Pool Nation is a game about, well, pool. You hit balls, get them in the pots, battle against AI or online, and rage at your friends for their skill at games. But there are a few flaws in this that make the game's screenshots exagerate how the game actually is.

First of all, the physics in the balls are AWFUL. Atleast 20 times (not exageration) during my career I got the ball stuck RIGHT AT THE POT and it didn't go in. If we got it to atleast the edge, give us credit or something. It happens to everybody playing pool, but come on, you didn't have to make it THAT realistic. Besides, who has two extra fingers on each hand?

Second, the camera controls are amazingly crap. You MOVE YOUR MOUSE to move the camera. That's nice. How about when I'm trying to hit the ball? Can you KEEP THE CAMERA WHERE IT'S AT????? Half the time I'm trying to fix my camera or looking down the cue or I'm a 500 feet tall man that looks on the very top of the pool table.

Last, the AI in this game is the hardest I've ever played. If you don't hit a ball, this AI will hit every striped/coloured ball it sees and you realise that you should use your time wisely because he hit all the balls, he's ready to hit the 8 ball, and you have to hurry and hit all your balls. It took me 3 times to beat the first guy. THE FIRST GUY. I have played pool as well, and I've went through the tutorial.

My honest review is that if this game is on sale, don't get your hopes too high but you could buy it. If it's at it's regular $10 price, it's not worth your money.

reviewText:
Most realistic physics engine in any cue sport game that I've played. It really is quite impressive, you can pull off just about any shot you can imagine if you have the know how. The AI players start off easy enough for you to get used to the control scheme (which isn't actually that intuitive, but once you get used to it, it's pretty damn good) and the game in general, and they range up to players so hard that if you give them an opportunity, they will clear almost any table. For some, that may be off putting, but it's not too far from reality, a lot of top players will clear almost any table if theyre having a good day.

Only issue i have really is that after a while, it gets kinda dull. Caning each AI player one after the other gets too easy after a while, and the only way to lose is to try and get 3 stars for the 3 challenges per match, but providing they don't ask you to do something that actually requires any thought, like a bank or kick shot, you have no excuse not to get all 3 stars.

They also try and spice it up with bonus matches of different disciplines of pool, which again is cool for a while, I still haven't mastered them all.

I don't really know what to suggest to make it better, it's pretty much as good as I can imagine a pool game getting, barring adding some kind of trick shot challenge, but then again, you may aswell make all shots a trick shot once you're used to the game.

8/10 - A very good time killer
